snippet: Villages like Sankuyo, Botswana, have lost income from trophy hunting while growing numbers of lions and elephants threaten their livestock and crops. Many in Africa argue that Western sensitivities are actually hurting conservation efforts.
abstract: Sankuyo, Botswana, is one of several rural African communities calling for return to trophy hunting, practice banned two years ago to protect wild animals; says national ban leaves residents, crops and livestock prey to rising number of animal predators and has reduced their incomes, which were often supplemented by hunting parties; request comes as more African nations face pressure to ban trophy hunting, fueled by tragic death of research subject, Cecil the lion, in Zimbabwe.
lead_paragraph: Villages like Sankuyo, Botswana, have lost income from trophy hunting while growing numbers of lions and elephants threaten their livestock and crops. Many in Africa argue that Western sensitivities are actually hurting conservation efforts.

headline.main: A Hunting Ban Saps a Village’s Livelihood
